elements.content: Hydrogen as a clean and environmentally friendly energy carrier has attracted extensive interest. Although Pt-based materials have been considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the high-cost and low-abundance hinder their practical application. Herein, we report the development of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) supported molybdenum phosphide (MoP) encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon (PC) nano-octahedrons derived from polyoxometalate-based metal–organic frameworks (POMOFs) by carbonization and subsequent phosphidation process. Impressively, combining the advantages of MoP, PC, and rGO, the composite shows superior electrocatalytic HER performance and stability, with a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, small Tafel slope of 53.6 mV dec–1, along with long-term durability for 10 h, which is comparable or even superior to those of the most promising MoP-based electrocatalysts in acid media reported to date. Most importantly, this work provides an elaborate strategy to design and fabricate high-efficiency and low-cost electrocatalysts utilizing POMOFs as precursors toward the HER.
elements.clean_text: Hydrogen as a clean and environmentally friendly energy carrier has attracted extensive interest. Although Pt-based materials have been considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the high-cost and low-abundance hinder their practical application. Herein, we report the development of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) supported molybdenum phosphide (MoP) encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon (PC) nano-octahedrons derived from polyoxometalate-based metal-organic frameworks (POMOFs) by carbonization and subsequent phosphidation process. Impressively, combining the advantages of MoP, PC, and rGO, the composite shows superior electrocatalytic HER performance and stability, with a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, small Tafel slope of 53.6 mV dec-1, along with long-term durability for 10 h, which is comparable or even superior to those of the most promising MoP-based electrocatalysts in acid media reported to date. Most importantly, this work provides an elaborate strategy to design and fabricate high-efficiency and low-cost electrocatalysts utilizing POMOFs as precursors toward the HER.

elements.content:
A MoP@PC/rGO composite derived from POMOFs shows superior electrocatalytic performance and long-term stability for the HER

Introduction

Electrochemical water-splitting to produce clean and sustainable hydrogen, as an ideal replacement for fossil fuels, has received much attention in recent years. In general, the state-of-the-art catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) are Pt-based materials because of its outstanding electrocatalytic activity. Nonetheless, the high-cost, scarcity, and instability preclude their broad application. As a result, it is of great urgency to exploit cost-effective and earth-abundant electrocatalysts toward HER. To overcome these issues, great efforts have been devoted to constructing alternative electrocatalysts with novel nanostructures and various components, such as transition-metal-based carbide, phosphide, nitride, and chalcogenides. Among them, molybdenum (Mo) based materials are regarded as the promising candidates owing to their earth-abundance and efficient activity. On the other hand, transition metals encapsulated with carbon layers or anchored onto carbon materials, as highly stable electrocatalysts, have also been proven to be a powerful strategy for fabrication of high-efficiency HER catalysts with enhanced stability.
elements.clean_text:
A MoP@PC/rGO composite derived from POMOFs shows superior electrocatalytic performance and long-term stability for the HER

Introduction

Electrochemical water-splitting to produce clean and sustainable hydrogen, as an ideal replacement for fossil fuels, has received much attention in recent years. In general, the state-of-the-art catalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) are Pt-based materials because of its outstanding electrocatalytic activity. Nonetheless, the high-cost, scarcity, and instability preclude their broad application. As a result, it is of great urgency to exploit cost-effective and earth-abundant electrocatalysts toward HER. To overcome these issues, great efforts have been devoted to constructing alternative electrocatalysts with novel nanostructures and various components, such as transition-metal-based carbide, phosphide, nitride, and chalcogenides. Among them, molybdenum (Mo) based materials are regarded as the promising candidates owing to their earth-abundance and efficient activity. On the other hand, transition metals encapsulated with carbon layers or anchored onto carbon materials, as highly stable electrocatalysts, have also been proven to be a powerful strategy for fabrication of high-efficiency HER catalysts with enhanced stability.

elements.content: Polyoxometalate-based metal–organic frameworks (POMOFs), consisting of both POMs and MOFs, have gained increasing global interest due to their intriguing architectures and excellent properties. In particular, utilizing POMOFs as precursors, novel carbon and/or metal-based nanostructured materials could be prepared, where POMOFs simultaneously offer both different metal (Mo, W, and V) and carbon sources. Noteworthily, the as-synthesized nanomaterials have two advantageous characteristics: (1) small-sized metal nanoparticles can be generated in situ during carbonization because noncoordinating POMs are encapsulated into the cavities of MOFs and (2) carbon layers originating from organic ligands of MOFs may efficiently prevent nanoparticles from agglomeration, sintering, and oxidation at high reaction temperature, and then enhance the catalytic activity and stability. Hence, developing an efficient route to synthesize Mo-based catalysts using POMOFs as precursors is of great importance for electrochemical energy applications but still remains a great challenge.
elements.clean_text: Polyoxometalate-based metal-organic frameworks (POMOFs), consisting of both POMs and MOFs, have gained increasing global interest due to their intriguing architectures and excellent properties. In particular, utilizing POMOFs as precursors, novel carbon and/or metal-based nanostructured materials could be prepared, where POMOFs simultaneously offer both different metal (Mo, W, and V) and carbon sources. Noteworthily, the as-synthesized nanomaterials have two advantageous characteristics: (1) small-sized metal nanoparticles can be generated in situ during carbonization because noncoordinating POMs are encapsulated into the cavities of MOFs and (2) carbon layers originating from organic ligands of MOFs may efficiently prevent nanoparticles from agglomeration, sintering, and oxidation at high reaction temperature, and then enhance the catalytic activity and stability. Hence, developing an efficient route to synthesize Mo-based catalysts using POMOFs as precursors is of great importance for electrochemical energy applications but still remains a great challenge.

elements.content: Recently, reduced graphene oxide (rGO), as catalytic materials and/or supports, has been extensively investigated toward HER due to the unique structure and physicochemical properties. Therefore, in view of the merit of POMOFs-based materials and rGO, we anticipate that the novel coupled molybdenum phosphide (MoP) and rGO nanomaterials could be synthesized utilizing POMOFs/GO as precursors, which are not easily prepared from sole MOFs precursors. Most importantly, to our knowledge, rGO-supported MoP-based hybrids derived from POMOFs have not been exploited for HER so far.
elements.clean_text: Recently, reduced graphene oxide (rGO), as catalytic materials and/or supports, has been extensively investigated toward HER due to the unique structure and physicochemical properties. Therefore, in view of the merit of POMOFs-based materials and rGO, we anticipate that the novel coupled molybdenum phosphide (MoP) and rGO nanomaterials could be synthesized utilizing POMOFs/GO as precursors, which are not easily prepared from sole MOFs precursors. Most importantly, to our knowledge, rGO-supported MoP-based hybrids derived from POMOFs have not been exploited for HER so far.

elements.content: Herein, for the first time, we have elaborately designed and fabricated MoP encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon nano-octahedrons supported on rGO (denoted as MoP@PC/rGO) composite utilizing POMOFs as precursors through a facile approach. Unexpectedly, taking advantage of the merits of MoP, PC, and rGO, the as-prepared MoP@PC/rGO hybrid, as an excellent HER electrocatalyst, demonstrates high catalytic activity and long-term stability.
elements.clean_text: Herein, for the first time, we have elaborately designed and fabricated MoP encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon nano-octahedrons supported on rGO (denoted as MoP@PC/rGO) composite utilizing POMOFs as precursors through a facile approach. Unexpectedly, taking advantage of the merits of MoP, PC, and rGO, the as-prepared MoP@PC/rGO hybrid, as an excellent HER electrocatalyst, demonstrates high catalytic activity and long-term stability.

elements.content: Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized accroding to the previous literature method. 0.2 g of Cu­(OAc)2·H2O, 0.3 g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate, and 0.07 g of l-glutamic acid were added into ultrapurified water (40 mL) to form solution A. The GO solution (7.5 mg, 5 mg mL–1) was dispersed into solution A dropwise under continuous stirring. Subsequently, 0.14 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was dissolved in ethanol (40 mL) and then added dropwise into the above solution with intense stirring. After 16 h, the mixture was collected by filtration and washing. Finally, the obtained sample was designed as NENU-5/GO after freeze dyring.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of NENU-5/GO and NENU-5

Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized accroding to the previous literature method. 0.2 g of Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O, 0.3 g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate, and 0.07 g of l-glutamic acid were added into ultrapurified water (40 mL) to form solution A. The GO solution (7.5 mg, 5 mg mL-1) was dispersed into solution A dropwise under continuous stirring. Subsequently, 0.14 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was dissolved in ethanol (40 mL) and then added dropwise into the above solution with intense stirring. After 16 h, the mixture was collected by filtration and washing. Finally, the obtained sample was designed as NENU-5/GO after freeze dyring.

elements.content:
In addition, NENU-5 was prepared under the identical procedures without adding GO solution.

Synthesis of Cu-MoO<sub>2</sub>@PC/rGO, MoO<sub>2</sub>@PC/rGO, and MoO<sub>2</sub>@PC

After flushing with Ar, the NENU-5/GO was heated from ambient temperature to 600 °C and then maintained for 6 h (defined as Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO). Subsequently, through etching treatment with 0.1 M FeCl3 solution, washing with distilled water, and drying in a vacuum oven at 70 °C, the MoO2@PC/rGO composite was obtained.
elements.clean_text:
In addition, NENU-5 was prepared under the identical procedures without adding GO solution.

Synthesis of Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO, MoO2@PC/rGO, and MoO2@PC

After flushing with Ar, the NENU-5/GO was heated from ambient temperature to 600 °C and then maintained for 6 h (defined as Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO). Subsequently, through etching treatment with 0.1 M FeCl3 solution, washing with distilled water, and drying in a vacuum oven at 70 °C, the MoO2@PC/rGO composite was obtained.

elements.content:
Additionally, MoO2@PC was prepared by the same method as that for MoO2@PC/rGO using NENU-5 as precursors.

Synthesis of MoP@PC/rGO, Cu<sub>3</sub>P-MoP@PC/rGO, and MoP@PC

In a typical procedure, a porcelain boat that loaded the MoO2@PC/rGO (100 mg) and (NH4)2HPO4 (500 mg) was put in the center of a tube furnace and then calcinated at 850 °C for 2 h under H2/Ar (10%/90% in volume rate). After cooling to room temperature naturally, the resultant sample was denoted as MoP@PC/rGO.
elements.clean_text:
Additionally, MoO2@PC was prepared by the same method as that for MoO2@PC/rGO using NENU-5 as precursors.

Synthesis of MoP@PC/rGO, Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO, and MoP@PC

In a typical procedure, a porcelain boat that loaded the MoO2@PC/rGO (100 mg) and (NH4)2HPO4 (500 mg) was put in the center of a tube furnace and then calcinated at 850 °C for 2 h under H2/Ar (10%/90% in volume rate). After cooling to room temperature naturally, the resultant sample was denoted as MoP@PC/rGO.

elements.content:
Simultaneously, the Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO and MoP@PC were prepared through the same method as that for MoP@PC/rGO but utilizing Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO and MoO2@PC as raw materials, respectively.

Instruments

The morphologies and structures of these materials were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (JEOL-2100F, JEOL), scanning electron microscope (JSM-7600F, JEOL), X-ray photon spectroscopy (PHI 5000 Verasa Probe, ULAC-PHI), powder X-ray diffraction (D/max 2500VL/PC, Japan), confocal micro Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR800, Horiba Jobin Yvon), and physisorption analyzer (ASAP 2050, Micromeritics).
elements.clean_text:
Simultaneously, the Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO and MoP@PC were prepared through the same method as that for MoP@PC/rGO but utilizing Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO and MoO2@PC as raw materials, respectively.

Instruments

The morphologies and structures of these materials were investigated by transmission electron microscopy (JEOL-2100F, JEOL), scanning electron microscope (JSM-7600F, JEOL), X-ray photon spectroscopy (PHI 5000 Verasa Probe, ULAC-PHI), powder X-ray diffraction (D/max 2500VL/PC, Japan), confocal micro Raman spectroscopy (LabRam HR800, Horiba Jobin Yvon), and physisorption analyzer (ASAP 2050, Micromeritics).

elements.content: Electrochemical tests were performed on a CHI 760D electrochemical station with a conventional three-electrode system. The working electrode is the sample modified glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with a diameter of 3 mm, the reference electrode is a saturated calomel electrode (SCE), and the counter electrode is a graphite electrode. A 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. A total of 4 mg of the measured sample were dispersed in 2 mL of a water/ethanol solution (V W/V N = 3/1) by sonication. Then, 5 μL of the resultant suspension was transferred on the surface of GCE with a loading of about 0.14 mg cm–2. After drying, 5 μL of Nafion solution (0.1 wt % aqueous solution) was dropped on the electrode surface and dried at room temperature. In this work, all of the potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) by calibrating as follows: E RHE = E SCE + 0.059 pH + E SCE θ (1). In 0.5 M H2SO4, E RHE = 0.241 V + E SCE (2). All polarization plots were recorded at 2 mV s–1. The stability test was carried out between −0.2 and +0.14 V at 100 mV s–1.
elements.clean_text:
Electrochemical Measurements

Electrochemical tests were performed on a CHI 760D electrochemical station with a conventional three-electrode system. The working electrode is the sample modified glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with a diameter of 3 mm, the reference electrode is a saturated calomel electrode (SCE), and the counter electrode is a graphite electrode. A 0.5 M H2SO4 aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte. A total of 4 mg of the measured sample were dispersed in 2 mL of a water/ethanol solution (V W/V N = 3/1) by sonication. Then, 5 μL of the resultant suspension was transferred on the surface of GCE with a loading of about 0.14 mg cm-2. After drying, 5 μL of Nafion solution (0.1 wt % aqueous solution) was dropped on the electrode surface and dried at room temperature. In this work, all of the potentials were converted to reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) by calibrating as follows: E RHE = E SCE + 0.059 pH + E SCE θ (1). In 0.5 M H2SO4, E RHE = 0.241 V + E SCE (2). All polarization plots were recorded at 2 mV s-1. The stability test was carried out between -0.2 and +0.14 V at 100 mV s-1.

elements.content: As shown in , the MoP@PC/rGO nanocomposite is fabricated as follows: (1) according to the previous report, the NENU-5/GO composite was obtained by in situ growth of NENU-5 on GO sheet via a coprecipitation approach followed by freeze-drying process. (2) A thermal conversion process in Ar flow was employed to convert NENU-5 into Cu-MoO2@PC; meanwhile, GO were spontaneously transformed to rGO. Then, the resultant sample was etched in 0.1 M FeCl3 solution to remove the Cu species (defined as MoO2@PC/rGO). (3) Subsequently, a phosphidation strategy was carried out to prepare the MoP@PC/rGO composite with MoO2@PC/rGO as the Mo-based precursor and (NH4)2HPO4 as the phosphorus source, respectively. The corresponding morphology and component are investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. From Figure S1a,b, the NENU-5 nanocrystals show octahedral or slightly truncated octahedral morphology with a size of around 2–3 μm, which are uniformly coated onto the GO sheets. As depicted in Figure S1c, the PXRD pattern of NENU-5/GO is similar to that of the simulated NENU-5, implying that the synthetic procedure of NENU-5 was not disturbed when GO was introduced. Figure S1d displays the TGA curve of NENU-5/GO, which involves two steps: between room temperature and 300 °C, the weight loss stems from the departure of H2O from MOFs and/or POMs, and the subsequent weight loss is ascribed to the conversion of NENU-5/GO to Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO at an elevated temperature of 300–600 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation and Characterization of MoP@PC/rGO Composite

As shown in , the MoP@PC/rGO nanocomposite is fabricated as follows: (1) according to the previous report, the NENU-5/GO composite was obtained by in situ growth of NENU-5 on GO sheet via a coprecipitation approach followed by freeze-drying process. (2) A thermal conversion process in Ar flow was employed to convert NENU-5 into Cu-MoO2@PC; meanwhile, GO were spontaneously transformed to rGO. Then, the resultant sample was etched in 0.1 M FeCl3 solution to remove the Cu species (defined as MoO2@PC/rGO). (3) Subsequently, a phosphidation strategy was carried out to prepare the MoP@PC/rGO composite with MoO2@PC/rGO as the Mo-based precursor and (NH4)2HPO4 as the phosphorus source, respectively. The corresponding morphology and component are investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), respectively. From Figure S1a,b, the NENU-5 nanocrystals show octahedral or slightly truncated octahedral morphology with a size of around 2-3 μm, which are uniformly coated onto the GO sheets. As depicted in Figure S1c, the PXRD pattern of NENU-5/GO is similar to that of the simulated NENU-5, implying that the synthetic procedure of NENU-5 was not disturbed when GO was introduced. Figure S1d displays the TGA curve of NENU-5/GO, which involves two steps: between room temperature and 300 °C, the weight loss stems from the departure of H2O from MOFs and/or POMs, and the subsequent weight loss is ascribed to the conversion of NENU-5/GO to Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO at an elevated temperature of 300-600 °C.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthetic Process of the MoP@PC/rGO Nanocomposite

elements.content: As shown in a,b, SEM images of the MoP@PC/rGO (yellow arrows) hybrid demonstrate that the sample with a particle size of about 1 μm well inherits the initial structure, which reveals a curly morphology with a wrinkled configuration, although its size decreases a little and surface becomes rough owing to the decomposition and shrinkage during the multistep treatments. From the surface of the octahedrons, many small pores (green arrows) can be clearly seen, which is beneficial to fill electrolyte and further promote electron transport. From c, the TEM image further proves the distribution of MoP@PC with mean particle size of 10 nm over the rGO sheets. A typical HRTEM image (inset of d) indicates obvious lattice spacing of 0.21 nm, assignable to the (101) crystalline plane of the MoP nanoparticle, which is entirely embedded by the continuous porous carbon and rGO sheets (d). This is advantageous to enhancing their interface contact and preventing the agglomeration and dissolution of nanoparticles, further boosting the electrocatalytic performance and stability of the hybrids. Additionally, scanning TEM (STEM) and the corresponding elemental mapping images of MoP@PC/rGO in e elucidate the homogeneous distribution of C, P, and Mo components in the composite. In particular, the distribution of the Mo element is almost overlapped with the region of P, suggesting the formation of MoP. That is, MoP nanoparticles are encapsulated in porous carbon; simultaneously, partial P atoms are also doped into porous carbon.
elements.clean_text: As shown in a,b, SEM images of the MoP@PC/rGO (yellow arrows) hybrid demonstrate that the sample with a particle size of about 1 μm well inherits the initial structure, which reveals a curly morphology with a wrinkled configuration, although its size decreases a little and surface becomes rough owing to the decomposition and shrinkage during the multistep treatments. From the surface of the octahedrons, many small pores (green arrows) can be clearly seen, which is beneficial to fill electrolyte and further promote electron transport. From c, the TEM image further proves the distribution of MoP@PC with mean particle size of 10 nm over the rGO sheets. A typical HRTEM image (inset of d) indicates obvious lattice spacing of 0.21 nm, assignable to the (101) crystalline plane of the MoP nanoparticle, which is entirely embedded by the continuous porous carbon and rGO sheets (d). This is advantageous to enhancing their interface contact and preventing the agglomeration and dissolution of nanoparticles, further boosting the electrocatalytic performance and stability of the hybrids. Additionally, scanning TEM (STEM) and the corresponding elemental mapping images of MoP@PC/rGO in e elucidate the homogeneous distribution of C, P, and Mo components in the composite. In particular, the distribution of the Mo element is almost overlapped with the region of P, suggesting the formation of MoP. That is, MoP nanoparticles are encapsulated in porous carbon; simultaneously, partial P atoms are also doped into porous carbon.

elements.content: Low and high magnification (a and b) SEM and (c and d) TEM images of MoP@PC/rGO. Green arrows, pores; yellow arrows, rGO. Inset of panel b: the particle-size distribution curve. Inset of panel d: HRTEM image of MoP@PC/rGO. (e) STEM image and elemental mapping of C, Mo, and P, respectively. Scale bar 500 nm.

Inset of panel b: the particle-size distribution curve. Inset of panel d: HRTEM image of MoP@PC/rGO. (e) STEM image and elemental mapping of C, Mo, and P, respectively. Scale bar 500 nm.

elements.content: For comparison, the SEM and TEM images of MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC were investigated in detail, respectively (FigureS2). Unexpectedly, it is found that these octahedrons are aggregated together as for MoP@PC, which could result in the decrease in active sites in comparison with MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC/rGO.
elements.clean_text: For comparison, the SEM and TEM images of MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC were investigated in detail, respectively (FigureS2). Unexpectedly, it is found that these octahedrons are aggregated together as for MoP@PC, which could result in the decrease in active sites in comparison with MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC/rGO.

elements.content: The PXRD patterns of the obtained samples were characterized and described in a. For MoO2@PC/rGO, the diffraction peaks at 26.16, 37.09, and 53.66° can correspond to the (011), (111), and (022) planes of monoclinic MoO2 (JCPDS, No. 76-1807). After phosphidation, all peaks are consistent with the hexagonal structure of MoP (JCPDS, No. 65-6487). No visible diffraction peaks of other phases are detected, implying that all MoO2 nanocrystals were successfully transformed into the MoP phase. In comparison with MoP@PC, the PXRD pattern of MoP@PC/rGO shows no apparent diffraction peak at 20–27°, demonstrating that MoP@PC nanoparticles are efficiently coated on the rGO surface, restraining the stacking of rGO sheets. Remarkably, the I D/I G ratio of MoP@PC/rGO is 2.58, higher than those of MoO2@PC/rGO (1.78) and MoP@PC (2.39), which reveals abundant defects are formed in MoP@PC/rGO after phosphidation, facilitating the exposure of electrochemical active sites and the increase in catalytic activity (b). The porous architectures of the as-prepared catalysts were further examined by N2 sorption isotherms. In c, these samples exhibit meso-porous structures with average pore diameter between 3 and 8 nm (d), as evidenced by large hysteresis loops. The BET surface areas of MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and MoP@PC/rGO are 489, 541, and 343 m2 g–1, respectively. The rich meso-pores are favorable to the penetration of liquid electrolyte, further improving the HER activity.
elements.clean_text: The PXRD patterns of the obtained samples were characterized and described in a. For MoO2@PC/rGO, the diffraction peaks at 26.16, 37.09, and 53.66° can correspond to the (011), (111), and (022) planes of monoclinic MoO2 (JCPDS, No. 76-1807). After phosphidation, all peaks are consistent with the hexagonal structure of MoP (JCPDS, No. 65-6487). No visible diffraction peaks of other phases are detected, implying that all MoO2 nanocrystals were successfully transformed into the MoP phase. In comparison with MoP@PC, the PXRD pattern of MoP@PC/rGO shows no apparent diffraction peak at 20-27°, demonstrating that MoP@PC nanoparticles are efficiently coated on the rGO surface, restraining the stacking of rGO sheets. Remarkably, the I D/I G ratio of MoP@PC/rGO is 2.58, higher than those of MoO2@PC/rGO (1.78) and MoP@PC (2.39), which reveals abundant defects are formed in MoP@PC/rGO after phosphidation, facilitating the exposure of electrochemical active sites and the increase in catalytic activity (b). The porous architectures of the as-prepared catalysts were further examined by N2 sorption isotherms. In c, these samples exhibit meso-porous structures with average pore diameter between 3 and 8 nm (d), as evidenced by large hysteresis loops. The BET surface areas of MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and MoP@PC/rGO are 489, 541, and 343 m2 g-1, respectively. The rich meso-pores are favorable to the penetration of liquid electrolyte, further improving the HER activity.

elements.content: (a) PXRD patterns, (b) Raman spectra, (c) N2 sorption isotherms, and (d) pore size distributions of different samples.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) PXRD patterns, (b) Raman spectra, (c) N2 sorption isotherms, and (d) pore size distributions of different samples.

elements.content: The valence state and chemical composition of the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid were reconfirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). From a, the survey spectrum elucidates that the composite contains C, P, Mo, and O elements. The corresponding element content is listed in Table S1. The high resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s in b shows the C–C/CC (284.6 eV), C–P (285.1 eV), C–O (286.6 eV), and O–CO (290.3 eV) peaks, respectively. The doublet at 129.7 and 130.5 eV in c is assigned to the P–Mo bonding. The additional two peaks at a higher binding energy of 133.6 and 134.4 eV are characteristic of P–C and P–O, respectively. In addition, two clear peaks at the Mo (3d) region (228.5/231.8 eV) are attributable to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 of Mo–P, respectively. As previously reported, due to surface oxidation of Mo species, the other sharp peaks at 236.5/233.6 eV (Mo6+ 3d3/2/3d5/2) and 233.1 eV (Mo4+ 3d3/2) can be assignable to MoO3 and MoO2, respectively. For comparison, MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC are tested by XPS, as displayed in Figures S3 and and Table S1.
elements.clean_text: The valence state and chemical composition of the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid were reconfirmed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). From a, the survey spectrum elucidates that the composite contains C, P, Mo, and O elements. The corresponding element content is listed in Table S1. The high resolution XPS spectrum of C 1s in b shows the C-C/CC (284.6 eV), C-P (285.1 eV), C-O (286.6 eV), and O-CO (290.3 eV) peaks, respectively. The doublet at 129.7 and 130.5 eV in c is assigned to the P-Mo bonding. The additional two peaks at a higher binding energy of 133.6 and 134.4 eV are characteristic of P-C and P-O, respectively. In addition, two clear peaks at the Mo (3d) region (228.5/231.8 eV) are attributable to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 of Mo-P, respectively. As previously reported, due to surface oxidation of Mo species, the other sharp peaks at 236.5/233.6 eV (Mo6+ 3d3/2/3d5/2) and 233.1 eV (Mo4+ 3d3/2) can be assignable to MoO3 and MoO2, respectively. For comparison, MoO2@PC/rGO and MoP@PC are tested by XPS, as displayed in Figures S3 and  and Table S1.

(c) Cyclic voltammograms within the range of no faradaic reaction Inset: The capacitive current at -0.009 V as a function of the scan rate for MoP@PC/rGO. (d) Polarization curves for MoP@PC/rGO initially and after 1000 CV cycles. Inset: Time-dependent current density curve for MoP@PC/rGO under a static overpotential of 232 mV for 10 h.

elements.content: A typical three-electrode setup was employed to investigate the HER electrocatalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. As a comparison, MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and 20% Pt–C were also evaluated, respectively. a indicates the polarization curves which were not corrected for IR loss. Impressively, commercial 20% Pt–C illustrates superior electrocatalytic activity, which is consistent well with the previous reports. In comparison with MoO2@PC/rGO (497.8 mV) and MoP@PC (109.5 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite shows a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, surpass the most of the MoP-based electrocatalysts reported so far (Table S2). Moreover, it is found that a rapid cathodic current increase when the potential is more negative than -81.5 mV. As is well-known, a 10 mA cm–2 current density is a crucial parameter toward HER. In contrast to MoO2@PC/rGO (857.2 mV) and MoP@PC (303.6 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite here has a lower overpotential requirement of 234.6 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm–2. What’s more, the current density of MoP@PC/rGO is higher than those of the counterpart samples over the whole potential region.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogen Evolution Reaction Performance of MoP@PC Composite

A typical three-electrode setup was employed to investigate the HER electrocatalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. As a comparison, MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and 20% Pt-C were also evaluated, respectively. a indicates the polarization curves which were not corrected for IR loss. Impressively, commercial 20% Pt-C illustrates superior electrocatalytic activity, which is consistent well with the previous reports. In comparison with MoO2@PC/rGO (497.8 mV) and MoP@PC (109.5 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite shows a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, surpass the most of the MoP-based electrocatalysts reported so far (Table S2). Moreover, it is found that a rapid cathodic current increase when the potential is more negative than -81.5 mV. As is well-known, a 10 mA cm-2 current density is a crucial parameter toward HER. In contrast to MoO2@PC/rGO (857.2 mV) and MoP@PC (303.6 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite here has a lower overpotential requirement of 234.6 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm-2. What's more, the current density of MoP@PC/rGO is higher than those of the counterpart samples over the whole potential region.

elements.content: Tafel plots of these materials were measured to assess the HER kinetics (b). The linear part of the Tafel slope for MoP@PC/rGO (53.6 mV dec–1) is slightly higher than that of commercial 20% Pt–C (30.0 mV dec–1), characteristic of rapid electron transport and a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. In contrast, MoP@PC and MoO2@PC/rGO show higher Tafel slopes of 61.1 and 123.2 mV dec–1. Strikingly, especially considering the values of Tafel slope, this outperforms most of the recently reported MoP-based electrocatalysts toward HER in acid media (Table S2). On the basis of the extrapolation of the Tafel plots, the exchange current density (j 0) of MoP@PC/rGO is determined to be about 1.05 × 10–3 mA cm–2, higher than those of MoP@PC (4.8 × 10–4 mA cm–2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (3.09 × 10–6 mA cm–2). Therefore, this strongly confirms that both rGO and phosphidation have significant influences on improving the electrocatalytic activity toward the HER. Such an intriguing onset potential and ultralow Tafel slope highlight that the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid is a promising HER electrocatalyst. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed by a cyclic voltammetry (CV) approach with different rates from 20 to 200 mV s–1, as indicated in c. The inset of c shows that the MoP@PC/rGO catalyst has a much higher double-layer capacitance (C dl, 20.5 mF cm–2) than MoP@PC (5.1 mF cm–2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (0.28 mF cm–2; Figure S5). This higher ECSA suggests a large electrochemical surface area and rich active sites for the HER, which results in the higher electrochemical activity of MoP@PC/rGO. In addition, compared to that of MoP@PC (0.013 s–1), the turnover frequency (TOF) of MoP@PC/rGO at the overpotential of 200 mV is calculated to be 0.019 s–1.
elements.clean_text: Tafel plots of these materials were measured to assess the HER kinetics (b). The linear part of the Tafel slope for MoP@PC/rGO (53.6 mV dec-1) is slightly higher than that of commercial 20% Pt-C (30.0 mV dec-1), characteristic of rapid electron transport and a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. In contrast, MoP@PC and MoO2@PC/rGO show higher Tafel slopes of 61.1 and 123.2 mV dec-1. Strikingly, especially considering the values of Tafel slope, this outperforms most of the recently reported MoP-based electrocatalysts toward HER in acid media (Table S2). On the basis of the extrapolation of the Tafel plots, the exchange current density (j 0) of MoP@PC/rGO is determined to be about 1.05 × 10-3 mA cm-2, higher than those of MoP@PC (4.8 × 10-4 mA cm-2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (3.09 × 10-6 mA cm-2). Therefore, this strongly confirms that both rGO and phosphidation have significant influences on improving the electrocatalytic activity toward the HER. Such an intriguing onset potential and ultralow Tafel slope highlight that the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid is a promising HER electrocatalyst. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed by a cyclic voltammetry (CV) approach with different rates from 20 to 200 mV s-1, as indicated in c. The inset of c shows that the MoP@PC/rGO catalyst has a much higher double-layer capacitance (C dl, 20.5 mF cm-2) than MoP@PC (5.1 mF cm-2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (0.28 mF cm-2; Figure S5). This higher ECSA suggests a large electrochemical surface area and rich active sites for the HER, which results in the higher electrochemical activity of MoP@PC/rGO. In addition, compared to that of MoP@PC (0.013 s-1), the turnover frequency (TOF) of MoP@PC/rGO at the overpotential of 200 mV is calculated to be 0.019 s-1.

elements.content: Durability is also significant criterion to examine the catalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO toward the HER. As demonstrated in d, the polarization curves were measured before and after 1000 CVs from −0.20 to +0.20 V at 100 mV s–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. Amazedly, it is found that insignificant change is presented, signifying the outstanding stability of MoP@PC/rGO in acid medium. Simultaneously, the long-term durability was also estimated by chronoamperometry and the MoP@PC/rGO exhibits almost unfading electrocatalytic activity for 10 h under a constant overpotential of 232 mV (inset of d). Additionally, the morphology and structure of MoP@PC/rGO after 1000 CVs were also characterized and shown in Figure S6. According to these aforementioned data, we infer that it may originate from the fascinating structure of MoP@PC/rGO. That is, the P-doped carbon layers can significantly prevent MoP nanoparticles from corrosion.
elements.clean_text: Durability is also significant criterion to examine the catalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO toward the HER. As demonstrated in d, the polarization curves were measured before and after 1000 CVs from -0.20 to +0.20 V at 100 mV s-1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. Amazedly, it is found that insignificant change is presented, signifying the outstanding stability of MoP@PC/rGO in acid medium. Simultaneously, the long-term durability was also estimated by chronoamperometry and the MoP@PC/rGO exhibits almost unfading electrocatalytic activity for 10 h under a constant overpotential of 232 mV (inset of d). Additionally, the morphology and structure of MoP@PC/rGO after 1000 CVs were also characterized and shown in Figure S6. According to these aforementioned data, we infer that it may originate from the fascinating structure of MoP@PC/rGO. That is, the P-doped carbon layers can significantly prevent MoP nanoparticles from corrosion.

elements.content: Considering the aforementioned results, the superior electrocatalytic properties of MoP@PC/rGO could be assignable to the following factors: (a) generally, MoP nanocrystallites as HER electrocatalysts show high activity because of its unique electronic structures. In the case of MoP@PC/rGO, the electron binding energy of Mo has a positive shift, while the binding energy of P has a negative shift, originating from the transfer of electrons from Mo to P. Therefore, the P and Mo function as the proton-acceptor center and hydride-acceptor, respectively, which are beneficial for the HER. When MoP particles are embedded in porous carbon, carbon layers could not only protect MoP nanoparticles from aggregating and then lower interfacial resistance but also facilitate rapid mass and electron transfer from the MoP nanoparticles to the electrode and short the pathways of charge transfer. (b) Moreover, the rich porous structures are expected to promote the penetration of electrolyte and enrich the protons, further enhancing the catalytic performance of MoP cores. (c) Additionally, P-doped in the carbon matrix has a prominent role in regulating the electronic structure of C atom, thus increasing the number of active sites. (d) Last but not least, the introduction of rGO could effectively improve the electrical conductivity and offer a continuous conducting network. All in all, MoP nanoparticles, PC, and rGO synergistically contribute to the superior performance of MoP@PC/rGO for the HER in acidic media.
elements.clean_text: Considering the aforementioned results, the superior electrocatalytic properties of MoP@PC/rGO could be assignable to the following factors: (a) generally, MoP nanocrystallites as HER electrocatalysts show high activity because of its unique electronic structures. In the case of MoP@PC/rGO, the electron binding energy of Mo has a positive shift, while the binding energy of P has a negative shift, originating from the transfer of electrons from Mo to P. Therefore, the P and Mo function as the proton-acceptor center and hydride-acceptor, respectively, which are beneficial for the HER. When MoP particles are embedded in porous carbon, carbon layers could not only protect MoP nanoparticles from aggregating and then lower interfacial resistance but also facilitate rapid mass and electron transfer from the MoP nanoparticles to the electrode and short the pathways of charge transfer. (b) Moreover, the rich porous structures are expected to promote the penetration of electrolyte and enrich the protons, further enhancing the catalytic performance of MoP cores. (c) Additionally, P-doped in the carbon matrix has a prominent role in regulating the electronic structure of C atom, thus increasing the number of active sites. (d) Last but not least, the introduction of rGO could effectively improve the electrical conductivity and offer a continuous conducting network. All in all, MoP nanoparticles, PC, and rGO synergistically contribute to the superior performance of MoP@PC/rGO for the HER in acidic media.

elements.content: To probe the effect of Cu species on catalytic activity for the HER, the Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO composite was synthesized under similar conditions, but Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO was used to replace MoO2@PC/rGO. From Figure S7a, b, it is clearly observed that many Cu3P and MoP nanoparticles are aggregated together, in comparison with MoP@PC/rGO. Nevertheless, when the Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO hybrid was treated by etching in FeCl3 solution and subsequent phosphidation, the complete removal of metallic Cu is evidenced by the absence of Cu3P-related peaks in the PXRD pattern (Figure S7c). On the other hand, the disappearance of Cu3P nanoparticles in the SEM and TEM images of the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid also supports the above-mentioned result (a–c). Notably, the BET surface area and pore volume of MoP@PC/rGO are larger than those of Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO (Figure S7d), which can improve electrolyte accessibility and benefit the practical application toward HER. Then, the electrocatalytic HER performance of Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO was assessed, as shown in . Noticeably, compared to MoP@PC/rGO, the resultant Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO composite with higher onset overpotential and larger Tafel slope exhibits relatively poor activity toward the HER. Thus, this effectively proves that the etching treatment plays key roles toward the improvement of electrocatalytic HER activity in this work.
elements.clean_text: To probe the effect of Cu species on catalytic activity for the HER, the Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO composite was synthesized under similar conditions, but Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO was used to replace MoO2@PC/rGO. From Figure S7a, b, it is clearly observed that many Cu3P and MoP nanoparticles are aggregated together, in comparison with MoP@PC/rGO. Nevertheless, when the Cu-MoO2@PC/rGO hybrid was treated by etching in FeCl3 solution and subsequent phosphidation, the complete removal of metallic Cu is evidenced by the absence of Cu3P-related peaks in the PXRD pattern (Figure S7c). On the other hand, the disappearance of Cu3P nanoparticles in the SEM and TEM images of the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid also supports the above-mentioned result (a-c). Notably, the BET surface area and pore volume of MoP@PC/rGO are larger than those of Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO (Figure S7d), which can improve electrolyte accessibility and benefit the practical application toward HER. Then, the electrocatalytic HER performance of Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO was assessed, as shown in . Noticeably, compared to MoP@PC/rGO, the resultant Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO composite with higher onset overpotential and larger Tafel slope exhibits relatively poor activity toward the HER. Thus, this effectively proves that the etching treatment plays key roles toward the improvement of electrocatalytic HER activity in this work.

elements.content: (a) Polarization curves and (b) Tafel plots of for Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO and MoP@PC/rGO.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Polarization curves and (b) Tafel plots of for Cu3P-MoP@PC/rGO and MoP@PC/rGO.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully fabricated a novel MoP@PC/rGO composite by MOFs-assisted approach via a facile carbonization followed by phosphidation processes for the first time. Assigned to the synergetic combination of MoP nanoparticles, PC, and rGO support, excellent electrocatalytic performance with low onset overpotential, small Tafel slope, as well as long-term stability is achieved for the HER, which is comparable to the best MoP-based catalysts for HER reported up to now. More importantly, this work opens new avenues for the construction of high-performance and inexpensive catalysts derived from POMOFs for energy conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have successfully fabricated a novel MoP@PC/rGO composite by MOFs-assisted approach via a facile carbonization followed by phosphidation processes for the first time. Assigned to the synergetic combination of MoP nanoparticles, PC, and rGO support, excellent electrocatalytic performance with low onset overpotential, small Tafel slope, as well as long-term stability is achieved for the HER, which is comparable to the best MoP-based catalysts for HER reported up to now. More importantly, this work opens new avenues for the construction of high-performance and inexpensive catalysts derived from POMOFs for energy conversion.

cln_elements.content: Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized accroding to the previous literature method. 0.2 g of Cu­(OAc)2·H2O, 0.3 g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate, and 0.07 g of l-glutamic acid were added into ultrapurified water (40 mL) to form solution A. The GO solution (7.5 mg, 5 mg mL–1) was dispersed into solution A dropwise under continuous stirring. Subsequently, 0.14 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was dissolved in ethanol (40 mL) and then added dropwise into the above solution with intense stirring. After 16 h, the mixture was collected by filtration and washing. Finally, the obtained sample was designed as NENU-5/GO after freeze dyring.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of NENU-5/GO and NENU-5

Graphene oxide (GO) was synthesized accroding to the previous literature method. 0.2 g of Cu(OAc)2⋅H2O, 0.3 g of phosphomolybdic acid hydrate, and 0.07 g of l-glutamic acid were added into ultrapurified water (40 mL) to form solution A. The GO solution (7.5 mg, 5 mg mL-1) was dispersed into solution A dropwise under continuous stirring. Subsequently, 0.14 g of 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid was dissolved in ethanol (40 mL) and then added dropwise into the above solution with intense stirring. After 16 h, the mixture was collected by filtration and washing. Finally, the obtained sample was designed as NENU-5/GO after freeze dyring.

cln_elements.content:
Hydrogen as a clean and environmentally friendly energy carrier has attracted extensive interest. Although Pt-based materials have been considered as the state-of-the-art catalysts for the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), the high-cost and low-abundance hinder their practical application. Herein, we report the development of reduced graphene oxide (rGO) supported molybdenum phosphide (MoP) encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon (PC) nano-octahedrons derived from polyoxometalate-based metal–organic frameworks (POMOFs) by carbonization and subsequent phosphidation process. Impressively, combining the advantages of MoP, PC, and rGO, the composite shows superior electrocatalytic HER performance and stability, with a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, small Tafel slope of 53.6 mV dec–1, along with long-term durability for 10 h, which is comparable or even superior to those of the most promising MoP-based electrocatalysts in acid media reported to date. Most importantly, this work provides an elaborate strategy to design and fabricate high-efficiency and low-cost electrocatalysts utilizing POMOFs as precursors toward the HER.

The PXRD patterns of the obtained samples were characterized and described in a. For MoO2@PC/rGO, the diffraction peaks at 26.16, 37.09, and 53.66° can correspond to the (011), (111), and (022) planes of monoclinic MoO2 (JCPDS, No. 76-1807). After phosphidation, all peaks are consistent with the hexagonal structure of MoP (JCPDS, No. 65-6487). No visible diffraction peaks of other phases are detected, implying that all MoO2 nanocrystals were successfully transformed into the MoP phase. In comparison with MoP@PC, the PXRD pattern of MoP@PC/rGO shows no apparent diffraction peak at 20–27°, demonstrating that MoP@PC nanoparticles are efficiently coated on the rGO surface, restraining the stacking of rGO sheets. Remarkably, the I D/I G ratio of MoP@PC/rGO is 2.58, higher than those of MoO2@PC/rGO (1.78) and MoP@PC (2.39), which reveals abundant defects are formed in MoP@PC/rGO after phosphidation, facilitating the exposure of electrochemical active sites and the increase in catalytic activity (b). The porous architectures of the as-prepared catalysts were further examined by N2 sorption isotherms. In c, these samples exhibit meso-porous structures with average pore diameter between 3 and 8 nm (d), as evidenced by large hysteresis loops. The BET surface areas of MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and MoP@PC/rGO are 489, 541, and 343 m2 g–1, respectively. The rich meso-pores are favorable to the penetration of liquid electrolyte, further improving the HER activity.

Hydrogen Evolution Reaction Performance of MoP@PC Composite

A typical three-electrode setup was employed to investigate the HER electrocatalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. As a comparison, MoO2@PC/rGO, MoP@PC, and 20% Pt–C were also evaluated, respectively. a indicates the polarization curves which were not corrected for IR loss. Impressively, commercial 20% Pt–C illustrates superior electrocatalytic activity, which is consistent well with the previous reports. In comparison with MoO2@PC/rGO (497.8 mV) and MoP@PC (109.5 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite shows a low onset overpotential of 62.3 mV, surpass the most of the MoP-based electrocatalysts reported so far (Table S2). Moreover, it is found that a rapid cathodic current increase when the potential is more negative than -81.5 mV. As is well-known, a 10 mA cm–2 current density is a crucial parameter toward HER. In contrast to MoO2@PC/rGO (857.2 mV) and MoP@PC (303.6 mV), the MoP@PC/rGO composite here has a lower overpotential requirement of 234.6 mV to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm–2. What’s more, the current density of MoP@PC/rGO is higher than those of the counterpart samples over the whole potential region.

Tafel plots of these materials were measured to assess the HER kinetics (b). The linear part of the Tafel slope for MoP@PC/rGO (53.6 mV dec–1) is slightly higher than that of commercial 20% Pt–C (30.0 mV dec–1), characteristic of rapid electron transport and a Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. In contrast, MoP@PC and MoO2@PC/rGO show higher Tafel slopes of 61.1 and 123.2 mV dec–1. Strikingly, especially considering the values of Tafel slope, this outperforms most of the recently reported MoP-based electrocatalysts toward HER in acid media (Table S2). On the basis of the extrapolation of the Tafel plots, the exchange current density (j 0) of MoP@PC/rGO is determined to be about 1.05 × 10–3 mA cm–2, higher than those of MoP@PC (4.8 × 10–4 mA cm–2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (3.09 × 10–6 mA cm–2). Therefore, this strongly confirms that both rGO and phosphidation have significant influences on improving the electrocatalytic activity toward the HER. Such an intriguing onset potential and ultralow Tafel slope highlight that the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid is a promising HER electrocatalyst. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed by a cyclic voltammetry (CV) approach with different rates from 20 to 200 mV s–1, as indicated in c. The inset of c shows that the MoP@PC/rGO catalyst has a much higher double-layer capacitance (C dl, 20.5 mF cm–2) than MoP@PC (5.1 mF cm–2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (0.28 mF cm–2; Figure S5). This higher ECSA suggests a large electrochemical surface area and rich active sites for the HER, which results in the higher electrochemical activity of MoP@PC/rGO. In addition, compared to that of MoP@PC (0.013 s–1), the turnover frequency (TOF) of MoP@PC/rGO at the overpotential of 200 mV is calculated to be 0.019 s–1.

Durability is also significant criterion to examine the catalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO toward the HER. As demonstrated in d, the polarization curves were measured before and after 1000 CVs from −0.20 to +0.20 V at 100 mV s–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. Amazedly, it is found that insignificant change is presented, signifying the outstanding stability of MoP@PC/rGO in acid medium. Simultaneously, the long-term durability was also estimated by chronoamperometry and the MoP@PC/rGO exhibits almost unfading electrocatalytic activity for 10 h under a constant overpotential of 232 mV (inset of d). Additionally, the morphology and structure of MoP@PC/rGO after 1000 CVs were also characterized and shown in Figure S6. According to these aforementioned data, we infer that it may originate from the fascinating structure of MoP@PC/rGO. That is, the P-doped carbon layers can significantly prevent MoP nanoparticles from corrosion.

Therefore, this strongly confirms that both rGO and phosphidation have significant influences on improving the electrocatalytic activity toward the HER. Such an intriguing onset potential and ultralow Tafel slope highlight that the MoP@PC/rGO hybrid is a promising HER electrocatalyst. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed by a cyclic voltammetry (CV) approach with different rates from 20 to 200 mV s-1, as indicated in c. The inset of c shows that the MoP@PC/rGO catalyst has a much higher double-layer capacitance (C dl, 20.5 mF cm-2) than MoP@PC (5.1 mF cm-2) and MoO2@PC/rGO (0.28 mF cm-2; Figure S5). This higher ECSA suggests a large electrochemical surface area and rich active sites for the HER, which results in the higher electrochemical activity of MoP@PC/rGO. In addition, compared to that of MoP@PC (0.013 s-1), the turnover frequency (TOF) of MoP@PC/rGO at the overpotential of 200 mV is calculated to be 0.019 s-1.

Durability is also significant criterion to examine the catalytic performance of MoP@PC/rGO toward the HER. As demonstrated in d, the polarization curves were measured before and after 1000 CVs from -0.20 to +0.20 V at 100 mV s-1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 solution. Amazedly, it is found that insignificant change is presented, signifying the outstanding stability of MoP@PC/rGO in acid medium. Simultaneously, the long-term durability was also estimated by chronoamperometry and the MoP@PC/rGO exhibits almost unfading electrocatalytic activity for 10 h under a constant overpotential of 232 mV (inset of d). Additionally, the morphology and structure of MoP@PC/rGO after 1000 CVs were also characterized and shown in Figure S6. According to these aforementioned data, we infer that it may originate from the fascinating structure of MoP@PC/rGO. That is, the P-doped carbon layers can significantly prevent MoP nanoparticles from corrosion.
